vocabulary.definition: A portable shelter made of cloth, supported by poles and ropes, used outdoors
An outdoor fire at a campsite, used for warmth, cooking, or as a focal point for social gatherings
A bag carried on one's back, typically used for carrying supplies while hiking or camping
A path or track made across a wild area or through a forest
The highest point of a hill or mountain
Providing or relating to views of impressive or beautiful natural scenery
An uncultivated, uninhabited, and inhospitable region
The uppermost branches of the trees in a forest, forming a more or less continuous layer of foliage
A deep, narrow gorge with steep sides
An area used for camping, often equipped with basic facilities
The leaves of a plant or tree
The physical features of an area of land, especially the shape of its surface

commonExpressions.meaning: To set up a tent
commonExpressions.example: We arrived at the campsite and quickly pitched our tent before it got dark.

commonExpressions.meaning: To begin a hike or journey
commonExpressions.example: We woke up early, packed our bags, and hit the trail by 7 AM.

commonExpressions.meaning: To live without modern comforts and conveniences
commonExpressions.example: During our camping trip, we decided to rough it by not bringing any electronic devices.

commonExpressions.meaning: To pause and enjoy a scenic landscape
commonExpressions.example: When we reached the mountaintop, we stopped to take in the breathtaking view of the valley below.

commonExpressions.meaning: To spend time in a natural environment, away from civilization
commonExpressions.example: After months of working in the city, Sarah decided to get back to nature by spending a week hiking in the mountains.

commonExpressions.meaning: A principle of minimizing one's impact on the environment while camping or hiking
commonExpressions.example: Remember to leave no trace by packing out all your trash and not disturbing the wildlife.

vocabulary.definition: Active at night
To spend the winter in a dormant state
An animal that naturally preys on others
An animal that feeds on plants
Seasonal movement of animals from one region to another
The way some animals hide themselves by blending in with their surroundings
The natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism
At risk of extinction
Tame and kept as a pet or on a farm
An innate, typically fixed pattern of behavior in animals in response to certain stimuli
A group of birds or sheep
A large group of animals, especially hoofed mammals, that live or are kept together

commonExpressions.meaning: A situation of fierce competition
commonExpressions.example: The corporate world can be a dog eat dog world, where everyone is looking out for themselves.

commonExpressions.expression: Let the cat out of the bag
commonExpressions.meaning: To reveal a secret
commonExpressions.example: I didn't mean to let the cat out of the bag about your surprise party.

commonExpressions.meaning: A view from a high elevation as if seen by a bird in flight
commonExpressions.example: From the top of the skyscraper, we had a bird's eye view of the entire city.

commonExpressions.meaning: Someone in an uncomfortable or unfamiliar situation
commonExpressions.example: As a country boy in the big city, John felt like a fish out of water.

commonExpressions.meaning: Information from the most reliable source
commonExpressions.example: I heard about the company's new policy straight from the horse's mouth - the CEO told me himself.

commonExpressions.meaning: Used to say that something will never happen
commonExpressions.example: He'll apologize when pigs fly - he's too proud to admit he was wrong.

vocabulary.definition: An item of clothing
Clothes, especially of a particular or formal type
An item that completes one's outfit, such as jewelry or a scarf
Cloth or other material produced by weaving or knitting fibers
A person who makes, repairs, or alters clothing professionally
The edge of a piece of cloth or clothing that has been turned under and sewn
Very fashionable or up-to-date
Of high quality and lasting value, or showing the best and most typical characteristics of a particular type of thing
Relaxed and informal in style or manner
A set of clothes worn together, typically for a particular occasion or purpose
The design and manufacture of fashionable clothes to a client's specific requirements and measurements
A collection of clothes belonging to one person

commonExpressions.meaning: To wear your best clothes to make a good impression
commonExpressions.example: For the job interview, John decided to dress to impress by wearing his finest suit.

commonExpressions.expression: Wear your heart on your sleeve
commonExpressions.meaning: To openly express your emotions
commonExpressions.example: Sarah always wears her heart on her sleeve, making it easy for everyone to know how she feels.

commonExpressions.meaning: To fit perfectly
commonExpressions.example: The tailor-made suit fit like a glove, accentuating all the right places.

commonExpressions.meaning: Wearing very formal or fancy clothes
commonExpressions.example: For their anniversary dinner, the couple was dressed to the nines in their most elegant attire.

commonExpressions.meaning: In someone else's situation or position
commonExpressions.example: Before you criticize him, try to put yourself in his shoes and understand what he's going through.

commonExpressions.meaning: To make an effort to improve
commonExpressions.example: If you want to pass the exam, you'll need to pull up your socks and study harder.

vocabulary.definition: A color or shade
Bright and striking
A soft and delicate shade of a color
Using only one color
A gradual change from one color to another
Colors opposite each other on the color wheel that create a strong contrast
One of the three basic colors (red, blue, yellow) from which all other colors can be made
A color made by mixing two primary colors
Very bright, full, and intense (referring to a color)
Colors such as black, white, grey, and sometimes brown and beige
A color with white added to it
A color with black added to it

commonExpressions.meaning: To go out and celebrate in a lively way
commonExpressions.example: After graduating, we decided to paint the town red and celebrate all night long.

commonExpressions.meaning: Very jealous
commonExpressions.example: When Sarah saw her friend's new car, she was green with envy.

commonExpressions.meaning: Unexpectedly
commonExpressions.example: Out of the blue, my old friend called me after years of no contact.

commonExpressions.meaning: To become very angry
commonExpressions.example: When John found out someone had scratched his new car, he saw red.

commonExpressions.meaning: An excellent chance for success
commonExpressions.example: The internship at the prestigious company was a golden opportunity for the young graduate.

commonExpressions.meaning: A person who is different from the rest of their family or group and is considered bad or embarrassing
commonExpressions.example: Tom was always seen as the black sheep of the family because he dropped out of college to pursue his art career.

vocabulary.definition: Showing little interest or enthusiasm
In a state of peaceful happiness and satisfaction
Feeling buried or drowning beneath a huge mass of something, especially work or stress
Experiencing or characterized by a sentimental longing for the past
Characterized by or feeling intense excitement and happiness
Feeling or expressing distress and annoyance resulting from an inability to change or achieve something
Calm, peaceful, and untroubled
Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone
Showing an ability to understand and share the feelings of another

commonExpressions.meaning: Extremely happy
commonExpressions.example: After getting her dream job, Sarah was on cloud nine for weeks.

commonExpressions.meaning: Sad or depressed
commonExpressions.example: John has been down in the dumps ever since his dog ran away.

commonExpressions.meaning: Nervous or excited about something
commonExpressions.example: Before her big presentation, Emily had butterflies in her stomach.

commonExpressions.expression: Wear your heart on your sleeve
commonExpressions.meaning: To express your emotions openly
commonExpressions.example: Tom always wears his heart on his sleeve, making it easy for everyone to know how he's feeling.

commonExpressions.meaning: Having conflicting emotions about something
commonExpressions.example: Lisa had mixed feelings about moving to a new city - excited for the opportunity but sad to leave her friends.

commonExpressions.meaning: To talk about something that has been troubling you
commonExpressions.example: After keeping his worries to himself for weeks, Mike finally decided to get it off his chest and talk to his friend.

vocabulary.definition: A device or piece of equipment designed to perform a specific task, typically in the home
A tool or implement, especially one for household use
A style or method of cooking, especially as characteristic of a particular country, region, or establishment
A set of instructions for preparing a particular dish, including a list of the ingredients required
Cook or heat food gently at or just below the boiling point
Soak (meat, fish, or other food) in a marinade
An ornamental addition to a dish
A cooking utensil used for beating eggs or cream
A small room or closet in which food, dishes, and utensils are kept
Salt, herbs, or spices added to food to enhance the flavor
Pour juices or melted fat over meat during cooking in order to keep it moist
(Of food, typically pasta) cooked so as to be still firm when bitten

commonExpressions.meaning: Used to say that time seems to pass more slowly when you're waiting for something to happen
commonExpressions.example: Stop checking the clock every minute. Remember, a watched pot never boils - your package will arrive when it arrives.

commonExpressions.expression: Too many cooks spoil the broth
commonExpressions.meaning: Too many people involved in managing an activity can ruin it
commonExpressions.example: The project failed because too many cooks spoiled the broth - everyone had different ideas and couldn't agree on anything.

commonExpressions.expression: That's the way the cookie crumbles
commonExpressions.meaning: Used to say that bad things happen and you cannot do anything about them
commonExpressions.example: I'm sorry you didn't get the job, but that's the way the cookie crumbles sometimes. Keep trying!

commonExpressions.expression: Out of the frying pan and into the fire
commonExpressions.meaning: Going from a bad situation to an even worse one
commonExpressions.example: After quitting his stressful job, Tom thought he'd be happier, but his new job was even more demanding - he'd jumped out of the frying pan and into the fire.

commonExpressions.expression: Take it with a pinch of salt
commonExpressions.meaning: To not completely believe something you are told
commonExpressions.example: You should take John's fishing stories with a pinch of salt - he tends to exaggerate quite a bit.

commonExpressions.meaning: To reveal secret information
commonExpressions.example: I trusted Sarah with my secret, but she spilled the beans to everyone at the party.
